titleInfo.title: Embodied Experience in the Piano Music of Contemporary Black Composers of the United States and United Kingdom

mods:mods.abstract: The purpose of this treatise is to examine the phenomenon of embodied experience in selected solo piano works of five Black composers of the United States and United Kingdom: Shawn Okpebholo, Hannah Kendall, Brian Raphael Nabors, James Lee III, and Eleanor Alberga. I use the term "embodied experience" primarily to consider how their music embodies African American and African identity, memory, and cultural expression. I also use it to describe my perspective as a performer having studied and engaged deeply with these works. Shawn Okpebholo ψαλμοὶ καὶ ὕμνοι καὶ ᾠδαὶ πνευματικαί (2012), Amazing Grace (2006) Hannah Kendall Processional (2018) Brian Raphael Nabors Piano Sonata (2016), Nocturne (2022) James Lee III Recuerdos Diaspoìricos (2018) Eleanor Alberga Jamaican Medley (1983), Oh Chaconne! (2014) The music of these five composers represents a synthesis of their cultural heritages, personal identities, musical backgrounds, values, and creative interests. Their piano works reflect the diversity of music by Black composers writing in the "classical contemporary" idiom. As the titles suggests, these works are shaped by both Western European and non-Western musical traditions, namely from East and West Africa, the United States, Papua New Guinea, the United Kingdom, Guyana, Australia, Cuba, and Jamaica. My treatise seeks to portray a balanced understanding of Black composers writing contemporary classical music and to promote further study of their music. Each chapter begins with biographical information and a summary of the composer's musical style, followed by an analysis of their respective piano works focusing on style elements and aesthetic aspects as they relate to the idea of embodied experience. Throughout the discussions, I offer ways to approach and engage with this music, as well as my perspectives on ways it expands and enriches the canon. My conclusion chapter invites readers and performers to consider their own embodied experiences, as well as their roles as active participants in "culture care," as they engage with music and everyday life. It also considers implications this music has for the classical music and future generations of Black musicians and composers.
mods:mods.note: A Treatise submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Music.
